name: Rough outline of my Cleric/Sorcadin build and my Swordflight channel
author: KainenMorden

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
I started a YT channel to document all the tough fights in Swordflight starting in Ch.3. I use a build that is mostly caster lvls but have beaten all those encounters with melee and have not used offensive magic during them and have not really used any at all except in a few situations where I used scrolls and rods. 



The build started as Human Cleric, War/Magic domains, then 1 lvl sorc for true strike, then 3 lvls of Pal, this ended Ch.1. Ch.2+3 its been nothing but Sorc lvls and I'm pretty sure I wont take any other dips into Pal. I did incur an XP penalty doing this that may have scaled down a few of the tough encounter spawns  early in Ch.3. 



Starting as cleric was for turn undead and access to cleric only scrolls that Pal can't use. Extend, Empower and Cleave have been very important feats. I took spell focus necromancy but haven't had to use any offensive magic on these tough fights and haven't used any at all besides a few fights here and there where I used a rod. I might "cheat" and respec that to Evocation, not sure yet but I've been able to just gish all the tough fights even though they do end up being time consuming. 



Check out the channel here:



https://www.youtube.com/@kainenmorden

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Welcome to the Guild, KainenMorden!

So what is it you want to discuss, or have I missed something? Are we talking about a variation on the Exalted Sorceress build, or is this something very different?

Cheers

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Well, I was curious if there were any other SF players here. Also, had a few quick questions. Does spell focus help overcome spell resistance? I'm not clear on this. 

The module does go to lvl 40 but the final chapter has not been released and it most likely will not be released for several years. The build at lvl 40 is hypothetically Sorc 36/cleric 1/paladin 3

Not sure if anyone thinks there is a better way to do it than this. This build has been played as a gish thus far but that may not be viable in later chapters.

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content: Also, if anybody can think up a cool name for this build, that would be appreciated. I've been requested to do a write up of the build by some SF players over on reddit.

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
btw, the char starts as cleric and turn undead is important so power attack and divine shield can be taken at 1st lvl and divine might can be taken at 3rd lvl with the first Pal lvl. 

The build relies on these 2 feats as well as true strike and scrolls of true strike.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ah, thank you.

Others in the Guild know Sorcerers much better than I, so maybe one or two of them will drop by and contribute.

In the meantime, I don't know if you've seen it, but we do have our own Swordflight thread, though it hasn't been added to in over a year now. You might find it of interest until someone else chimes in here.

Cheers

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content: Thanks!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
KainenMorden wrote: ↑
Nov 26, 2022
Does spell focus help overcome spell resistance? I'm not clear on this.
As for spell resistance: A high number of caster levels in your build is the most important for beating SR. The spell penetration feats add to beating SR. The breach spells and KainenMorden's disjunction will lower the SR of the target.
As for spell focus: A high casting stat e.g. charisma for sorcerers will give a higher spells DC making it harder to save vs the spells. The SF feats will increase the DC of the spells of a specific school, making it even harder to save vs those spells.

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
So my question is, with something like isaac's or icestorm that has no save, does spell focus help at all or only spell penetration helps? 

Basically I'm in a tough spot because I only have 3 feats to boost my offensive magic and I'm not sure exactly what direction to go in.

Per the modules creator, the only offensive spell that is absolutely necessary is sunbeam which does have a save. At the same time, I may not be able to do melee damage because of a low AB. I have been able to beat every fight in the first 3 chapters with melee but it may not go that way in these later chapters so making sure my isaacs and icestorms do damage is important, I do have the empower feat for those spells but don't have maximize.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
So my question is, with something like isaac's or icestorm that has no save, does spell focus help at all or only spell penetration helps?
Since there is no save involved, the only thing that will come into question (besides dr) is spell resistance.  Thus, Spell Penetration is the helpful feat here (and of course, anything that can lower enemy spell resistence).

Spell Focus raises the DC of the spell, which doesn't affect sr (it affects the save).

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Thanks!

Also something I was thinking about, how can I increase my spell resistance as a pal/sorc/cleric? Since I only have 1 lvl of cleric, I would imagine a scroll of spell resistance would be best or if I found items that give spell resistance.

Also, what's the best way to resist elemental damage? I think its elemental shield, energy buffer, would resist elements on top of this help?

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content: Oh, sorry for double post, what are the best ways in your opinion to lower enemy AC with spells? I know slow would help as well as some of the bigbys spells, sun beam, stinking cloud? Do these all stack as well?

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content: Guys, please forgive me, one other thing, what is the best way to resist physical damage? I use premonition, are there any tips or tricks to make it work better? or to use shadow conjuration with stone skin? Keep in mind, I'm a pretty big nwn noob but familiar with dnd in crpgs in general. Appreciate all your help so far.

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content:
A couple suggestions/answers.
Resisting physical damage with your build is mainly going to be with the premonition and stoneskin line of spells. Also in many modules (I don't know this one) there are things like archer's belts,swordsman's belt etc. Giving additional resistance to piercing,cutting, and blunt attacks respectively.

I like to use darkness spells (when I have true seeing/ultravision) and grease spells to make enemies easier to hit. When they're down on the ground, they're easy to hit. In this module, one might have to stay on the periphery of the grease area. It sounds like to me that knockdown protection is not that common.

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Thanks, I'll keep this all in mind!

I do have true seeing and time stop at my disposal as well, I'm already a lvl 20 sorc. I have just been continuing to melee as long as possible before I "respec" my feats since I was so uncertain on what would be best for my build. 

I have corresponded with the creator of the module and in his opinion, investing in spell penetration feats wouldn't be best especially since my feats are limited, he said:

Spell Penetration feats may also not be that useful long term, as high level casters who are not significantly multi-classed can usually beat whatever spell resistance they encounter without it, with the typical exception of certain high level monk builds, whose spell resistance can be so high as to be unbeatable anyway even with all those feats.

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Another thing before I forget, I think I'm going to take a cleric lvl now to get rid of my multiclass xp penalty, do arcane and divine caster lvls combine when determining if you can resist a dispel?

what determines if you resist a dispel on divine shield and divine might feats?

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
About resisting damage...   don't forget the lowly Ghostly Visage spell.   Not only does it soak 5 damage, but it negates all spells up to  level 1.   How many times have those goblin shamans hit you with too many magic missiles to count, or the frost rays....

from the wiki:
"Description: The caster is surrounded by a ghostly nimbus of light that grants damage reduction 5/+1, prevents all spells of level 1 or lower from affecting the caster, and grants 10% concealment."

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:

Also, is the only good way to defend against repeated castings of isaac's by putting up and recasting empowered/greater spell mantle?

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:

GDL even did a whole build based on that...

Vicar of the Void

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Well, actually, I'm sorc lvl 21/ cleric 1/ paladin 3, its actually been a really fun build to play. 

I'll be honest, not sure if the module even includes scrolls of silence and also not sure how well the scrolls would work against higher lvl casters but you've given me a good idea to try if like I said, silence scrolls can be purchased.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
KainenMorden wrote: ↑
Nov 28, 2022
Also, is the only good way to defend against repeated castings of isaac's by putting up and recasting empowered/greater spell mantle?
It is one way, but not the only one.
If it is a single mage opponent, use Time stop, debuff him with Mords if necessary and kill him with a death spell (fortitude is one of his low saves) or use IGMS yourself. If he has a spell mantle up, Flame arrow will be very effective to strip it away because every arrow counts as a lvl 3 spell attack.
If you face multiple mages, Wail can be very effective unless they all have their spell mantles up. In that case, I would try Greater sanctuary and come back when the mantles wear off.

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Awesome advice, thanks! 

I'm going to be fighting a strong spellcaster in the module sometime soon, I plan on recording and uploading it to youtube, I'll drop a link here for anyone that's interested when the time comes. 

Also, is there any way to quantify how far behind in levels a character with a multi class xp penalty is from where they would be if they didnt have that penalty? I took a penalty not realizing that encounter spawns would slightly scale down and wondered what my lvl would have been at if I didn't take that penalty.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
If you're playing a human or half-elf you'll never get an xp penalty higher than 20% as they have no favoured class. Other races can receive a 40% penalty if not using their favoured class and don't keep their classes within a level of each other. There are no penalties for using a prestige class (although I'm told EE seems to be including them as well currently, which is something of a nightmare).

So, for every level-up where the lesser 2 classes are two or more levels apart the PC receives only 80 out of every 100 xp with a 20% penalty. I'm sure you can extend that through to work out what level you would otherwise have achieved.

Of course, your difficulty level setting also plays a part, but that's a different story.

Cheers

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Due to a current issue (BeamDog WILL NOT comment on it or address it for a year now), Humans and Half-Elves suffer a harsh XP penalty IF a Prestige Class exceeds the level of one of their base classes.

This needs to be said.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
KainenMorden wrote: ↑
Nov 30, 2022
At what lvl do my spells/buffs become undispellable? 
Caster level 25.
Note that your spells can still be breached and, if the AI targets the ground, you can still be dispelled.  Also, Mord's will dispel you (depending on the opposing Caster level vs yours).

posts.content: AFAIK, repeat castings of Premonition just replace old castings, meaning that the damage is refreshed - not sure about the duration, but it is probably also refreshed.

At my caster lvl, it should give +13 ab and I use improved invisibility and my strength is buffed by 7 with empowered bulls strength. posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I am not aware of any DP/DS, etc bug.  What exactly do you mean here?

I assume you are using a custom version of Tenser's - you should look into it.  It may be buffing your Str.  Str does not count towards the +20 AB cap.

Which more than likely, is going to be affected by the +20 AB cap.  So if TT brings you to the +20 AB cap, then DP is not going to help increase your AB any further.

posts.author: webshaman1

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: KainenMorden

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Aha.
The caster becomes an engine of destruction, gaining a +1 attack bonus for every 2 caster levels, a +4 natural armor AC bonus, 20 strength, 22 dexterity, 18 constitution, +5 to their fortitude saving throws, and +1d6 additional hit points per caster level.
What level is your character?

The Attack Bonus of this spell counts towards the +20 AB cap.  It also has the following drawbacks :
  • A drawback to this spell is a possible lowering of armor class (since bonuses from items do not apply while transformed).
  • While transformed by this spell, a character wields Tenser's Sword, a +3 longsword with a 1d6 fire damage bonus. (This may be detrimental to a character with monk levels.)

anyways, does anyone have any ideas on time stop spell combinations?

also, when hasted, how many spells can you cast during a time stop?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
When Hasted, one can cast two spells before Time Stop ends.

As for combos, the normal ones are TS - IGMS - IGMS - TS, rinse, repeat.

For tough SR foes, one might wish to toss a Mord's in first (and against foes who have buffed up). Sometimes, it might be better to use a flame arrow against a caster with magic shields up.

For huge numbers of m0bs, I'd go with TS - Horrid Wilting, Horrid Wilting, TS, rinse, repeat until all are dead.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: KainenMorden
posts.content:
Also, a user said my exalted sorceress variant is the height of NWN munchkinism. That doesn't bother me because I admit it can be seen as a cheesy build but I was very inexperienced with NWN and played through what is considered one of if not the most challenging (well done) combat modules.

I would think some combo of cleric/rdd would be more powerful in some ways than my build but I think any full caster played correctly is very powerful.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Some people confuse the term munchkin with knowing how to build a powerful character and play one.
Both terms are often used together with the term power player as an antithesis to role-playing.
Munchkins are usually frowned upon for destroying a good role-playing environment whit their ruthless style.
IMO what is important in a RP oriented environment is how you play the character, not how you build it.
The term power player is often used to describe people who want to engage in combat and explore areas for the gain of XP and loot and prefer that to engaging in immersive roleplay with other players.
Both styles, RP and PP have their supporters. Personally I can enjoy both.
Sometimes playing flawed characers gives more options for roleplay. And playing a character without a pre-set build progression can give greater RP freedom when developing the character according to what happens during play, at the cost of optimisation of the build power wise. But you can still be a good roleplayer and enjoy great roleplay even if your character is powerful.
What I don't like is the attitude of people saying "only what I do is the right thing".

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Mick is correct here.

RP Nazis are among the worst offenders, right up there with Griefers.

There is no VALID reason why someone cannot RP a powerful build.

None.

That said, there are those Players who will do anything to abuse a system to get ridiculously powerful characters, just so that they can dominate play.

Those are Munchkin types.

Players like "my sister DMed me and I got this fabulous +10000 Sword of Everything!" are like this.

Basically, the main difference in playstyle really boils down to "why play this build" sort of thing.

My way of seeing things - play that which is fun for you (this is entertainment and it should be fun) AND doesn't disrupt the fun for others.

That's a win-win in my book.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

Thanks for the responses.

Well, it's a single player module I'm playing.

This person just seemed butt hurt I pointed out that Swordflight isn't balanced for the PRC. I think it would be impossible to balance anything for the PRC, too many races/class combinations.

I've corresponded with the creator of the module quite a bit in the past. He designed it for experienced nwn players that wanted a challenge and he assumed they would power build. He also designed it so that a non optimized character could complete it with the right tactics.

This user also complained that the monster power lvls are "wrong" because the module gives them abilities/stats that they didn't have in base NWN.

I pointed out how this was irrelevant, that's like complaining NWN doesn't completely model pnp as far as monsters go. It's a videogame.

Similarly, another user showed a vid of them defeating a dragon in a later chapter of the module but they removed the +12 cap on boosting ability scores through spells/items. They justified it by saying it was an option in EE. Another user pointed out the module wasn't designed with that feature in mind, similar levels of butthurt ensued.

Imo, this module isn't just combat and has many rping opportunities and I didn't feel like having a powerful build affected that aspect at all.

I could see in a PW with other players, someone who is not focusing on rping while others are would be bad form.

I think the butthurt was more that I explained if you thought the module was unfair, you don't known NWN well enough. I suppose they took that as a personal attack which it was not intended to be.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
First of all, one cannot "cheat" in a closed, single-player environment.  This is because it is impossible to cheat on yourself (unless you are schitzophrenic).

In light of that, as long as I have not agreed to any conditions with anyone else prior to play, I can do whatever I like in my SP game and everyone else can fook off.

Second, yes, it *IS* possible to balance NWN play with the prc - I used to build and DM on a prc PW (The Silver Marshes), back in the day (and I had the first PW that used the prc, The Playground).

It takes a shitfookton of work, though, and most don't have that sort of time nor resources.

At the end of the day, play what is fun for you and doesn't hurt the fun of others.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
webshaman1 wrote: ↑
Feb 19, 2023
First of all, one cannot "cheat" in a closed, single-player environment.  This is because it is impossible to cheat on yourself (unless you are schitzophrenic).

In light of that, as long as I have not agreed to any conditions with anyone else prior to play, I can do whatever I like in my SP game and everyone else can fook off.
Quite agree, Webby. Apart from anything else, you wouldn't be able to go back to the same module twice, because if you did you would be forced not to prepare yourself for that dragon you know is over the hill you're approaching having been fried by it the first time, thus ending up as an omelette again, and again, and again (admittedly my cooking metaphor might have slid from the skillet somewhat). So you'd either have to get everything right the first time or resign yourself to never finishing the module.

That said, you well know that I'm not a "true" power gamer myself, endeavoring to squeeze every drop of xp and hit the level 40 hot spot asap. Rather, I tend more to builds that play well throughout their levels and immerse themselves in the various plots and sub-plots. Now, the second part of that is absolutely "proper" role play, whereas the first bit is probably more like self-gimping. Which is grand for me, but may well irk others. Give yourself your own parameters, then build the best PC you can within those margins.

One of the great things about NwN (and indeed D&D more broadly) is that one is, as you rightly say, able to enjoy playing your own way (unless you have a singularly crappy DM, ofc). Why even bother, otherwise?

First of all, one cannot "cheat" in a closed, single-player environment.  This is because it is impossible to cheat on yourself (unless you are schitzophrenic).

In light of that, as long as I have not agreed to any conditions with anyone else prior to play, I can do whatever I like in my SP game and everyone else can fook off.

Second, yes, it *IS* possible to balance NWN play with the prc - I used to build and DM on a prc PW (The Silver Marshes), back in the day (and I had the first PW that used the prc, The Playground).

It takes a shitfookton of work, though, and most don't have that sort of time nor resources.

At the end of the day, play what is fun for you and doesn't hurt the fun of others.
I agree, I never told the player not to use PRC or PRC is cheating just that the module was designed for base NWN. Players should play as they like.
